summary: This is a reply memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team in support of supplemental pretrial motions related to the S2 superseding indictment. It argues that the 2007 Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) immunizes Maxwell from prosecution on specific counts, that prosecuting her would violate double jeopardy, and that the government is withholding exculpatory Brady material related to a key witness (Accuser-4).

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, accused of conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein. Her defense team argues the NPA grants her immunity and that the prosecution is an overreach.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the underlying sex trafficking case. The document discusses the 2006-2008 Florida investigation into him and the NPA he signed, which the defense argues also immunizes Maxwell.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, who signed and filed this reply memorandum.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C., listed on the filing.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C., listed on the filing.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from the Law Offices of Bobbi C. Sternheim, listed on the filing.

persons.name: Accuser-4
persons.context: A key witness whose allegations form the basis for Counts Five and Six of the S2 indictment. The defense argues her prior statements to the FBI (which did not mention Maxwell) are exculpatory Brady material.

persons.name: Special Agent Kuyrkendall
persons.context: An FBI agent who testified before the grand jury about Accuser-4's 2007 interview and the scheduling of massage appointments.

connections.description: Maxwell is alleged to have conspired with Epstein in sex trafficking crimes. The defense argues the NPA Epstein signed also immunized his 'potential co-conspirators,' including Maxwell.
Everdell is one of the lead attorneys representing Maxwell in this criminal case.
Accuser-4 is a witness whose allegations form the basis for charges against Maxwell. The defense disputes her account, noting she did not mention Maxwell in her initial 2007 FBI interview.
Accuser-4 is an alleged victim of Epstein. Epstein paid a settlement to her as part of the NPA conditions.

events.title: Florida Investigation of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: A thorough investigation conducted by the Palm Beach FBI and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida into Jeffrey Epstein's crimes.

events.title: Accuser-4's FBI Interview
events.description: Accuser-4 was interviewed by the Palm Beach FBI in connection with the Florida Investigation. The defense notes she did not mention Ghislaine Maxwell during this initial interview.

events.title: Signing of Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA)
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, which resolved his federal criminal liability and included immunity for 'potential co-conspirators.'

events.title: Epstein's Florida State Court Plea
events.description: As a condition of the NPA, Epstein pleaded guilty in Florida state court to one count of solicitation of prostitution and one count of solicitation of minors to engage in prostitution, and registered as a sex offender.

events.title: Filing of Maxwell's Omnibus Reply Memorandum
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files this reply memorandum in support of supplemental pretrial motions seeking dismissal of charges.

keyFacts: The defense argues the 2007 Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) immunizes Ghislaine Maxwell from prosecution on Counts One, Three, Five, and Six of the S2 superseding indictment, as she was a 'potential co-conspirator' covered by the agreement.

The defense contends that prosecuting Maxwell on Counts Five and Six violates the Double Jeopardy Clause because Epstein was already punished for those offenses (via the NPA's conditions), and seeking punishment from Maxwell for the same acts constitutes duplicative punishment.

A key witness, Accuser-4, did not mention Ghislaine Maxwell during her initial 2007 FBI interview, which the defense argues is exculpatory Brady material that the government is wrongfully withholding.
The defense frames the SDNY prosecution as a 'do-over' and 'prosecutorial overreach' by an office dissatisfied with the outcome of the earlier Florida investigation and NPA.

The document references that Epstein paid over $12.5 million in settlements to alleged victims, including approximately $446,000 to the person believed to be Accuser-4, as part of fulfilling the NPA conditions.
